article.body: President Trump is back home at the White House. The commander-in-chief tweeted on Monday afternoon that he was leaving Walter Reed Medical Center, just days after he moved into the Bethesda, Md. hospital for âfurther evaluationâ and out of âan abundance of cautionâ after revealing he had tested positive for COVID-19. âI feel better than I did 20 years ago!â he added, urging his followers not to fear the coronavirus or âlet it dominate your life.â iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Upon his return to 1600 Pennsylvania Ave., he promptly ignited controversy by taking off his mask, even though his physician Dr. Sean Conley said earlier in the day that the president is still contagious and âmay not entirely be out of the woods yet.â Still, his clinical status supported a âsafeâ return home, Trumpâs medical team said. Hereâs what we know so far about his prognosis and treatment, as well as how theyâre impacting the federal government and the election. The presidentâs medical treatment The president relocated from the White House to Walter Reed on Friday, the same day that he and first lady Melania Trump revealed they had tested positive for COVID-19. He was being treated with Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc.âsÂ experimental neutralizing antibody cocktail, Gilead Sciences Inc.âsÂ remdesivir, and the steroid dexamethasone. The latter is often used to treat severely ill COVID-19 patients. Trump was also given supplemental oxygen at least once, his physician Dr. Sean Conley confirmed on Sunday. And the president is taking zinc, vitamin D, an acid reducer, melatonin and aspirin. Read:President Trump is prescribed a third drug to combat his COVID-19 infection The president has been reassuring the public about his prognosis Trump told the American people that âI feel much better nowâ in a video statement from Walter Reed late Saturday, and that the first lady was doing well, too. Read:âI wasnât feeling so well. I feel much better nowâ: Full transcript of Trumpâs video address from Walter Reed The president also briefly left Walter Reed on Sunday night to take a motorcade ride past his supporters, who had been lining up outside since he was admitted. Some doctors expressed alarm over the move, including an attending physician from Walter Reed, James Phillips, who called it âinsanityâ and âpolitical theater.â Phillips tweeted, âEvery single person in the vehicle during that completely unnecessary Presidential âdrive-byâ just now has to be quarantined for 14 days.â Read: Hereâs what doctors are saying about Trumpâs motorcade outside Walter Reed to wave at supporters His medical team told reporters on Monday afternoon that Trump had not recorded a fever in more than 72 hours, and his oxygen levels were normal. And once the president returns to the White House, Conley added that Trump will be âsurrounded by world-class medical care 24/7.â Indeed Dr. Daniel McQuillen, senior staff physician at Lahey Hospital & Medical Center in Burlington, Mass., told MarketWatch that the president is ânot really going home from a medical perspective.â Thatâs why his Walter Reed residency has been a relatively quicker trip in and out of the hospital compared to other coronavirus patients. Whatâs more, the president tweeted âDonât be afraid of Covid. Donât let it dominate your life,â on Monday, sparking heated Twitter exchanges. Read:âDonât ever, ever underestimate the potential of the pandemicâ: 5 reasons scientists say you should be afraid of COVID-19 There have been conflicting reports about the presidentâs health Questions remain about the presidentâs medical condition, as well as the date of his last negative COVID-19 test and when he first began treatment for the virus after his personal physician made some statements that have conflicted with what White House chief of staff Mark Meadows told reporters. This has led Dr. Ashish Jha, the dean of theÂ Brown University School of Public Health,Â to call for âradical transparencyâ on Trumpâs illness. âAs the president undergoes treatment for his emerging symptoms, the public must receive daily, honest updates about the presidentâs condition, not from White House staff but from his medical team,â Jha said in a statement. A recent Rose Garden event is being eyed as a possible super-spreader scenario Dr. Jha also tweeted that it is a reasonable assumption that the president was infected sometime between Saturday, Sept. 26 â when he announced Amy Coney Barrett as his Supreme Court candidate in the Rose Garden â and the following Monday, and that he could have been infectious as early as Tuesday, when he faced former Vice President Joe Biden in the first presidential debate. Biden has so far tested negative for the virus. Trumpâs chief of staff also warned on Friday morning that all White House staff had been tested for COVID-19, and he expects thatÂ âas this virus continues to go on, other people in the White House will certainly have a positive test result.â Read:Hereâs a reverse timeline of where Trump has been That Rose Garden event is being eyed as a potential âsuper-spreaderâ event, as several attendees including the president and first lady, Trumpâs senior adviser Hope Hicks, former White House adviser Kellyanne Conway, Trumpâs campaign manager Bill Stephen and former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie have all tested positive for COVID-19. Attorney General William Barr, who was also at the Rose Garden event, will quarantine out of caution despite testing negative for the virus so far. White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany tested positive on Monday morning. Read:Potential Washington COVID-19 super-spreader events have everyone asking again: How does contact tracing work? Whatâs more, U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnellÂ canceled Senate votes for the next two weeks after three Republican Senators tested positive for the virus. The confirmation hearings for Trumpâs Supreme Court Justice nominee Amy Coney Barrett were set to continue, however. What if Trump becomes too sick to serve as president? Under the Constitution, Vice President Mike Pence would take the reins in the event that Trump was unable to perform his duties for health reasons, and he would likely pick another Republican to serve as his own vice president. If something happened where Pence was unable to step in as commander-in-chief, Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi would be next in line.Â Hereâs a detailed look at the presidential line of succession. What this means for the election Thereâs a lot still up in the air, such as whether the remaining two presidential debates, on Oct. 15 and Oct. 22, will be canceled. They will most likely be impacted in some way. There is some speculation that they may not be in-person events. âSaturday Night Liveâsâ parody of the first debate suggested that it may end up being the only presidential debate of this election. The vice presidential debate between Mike Pence and Sen. Kamala Harris was still on track to take place on Wednesday, Oct. 7. The president will put in-person campaigning on pause while he quarantines, with his campaign manager Bill Stepien announcing last Friday that these are being moved to virtual events or are being temporarily postponed. Trump tweeted a series of campaign-style slogans on Monday morning that called upon his supporters to vote, including: âBIGGEST TAX CUT EVER, AND ANOTHER ONE COMING. VOTE!â and âSTOCK MARKET HIGHS. VOTE!â His â401(K). VOTE!â tweet drummed up a lot of Twitter chatter, as some users expressed dissatisfaction with the state of their 401(k) plans in recent months. Biden has continued campaigning, although his team pulled down their attack ads as the president was moved to Walter Reed on Friday. (The Trump campaign did not reciprocate.) Bidenâs schedule still saw him traveling to Florida on Monday for campaign events including a town hall.
